Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_91362: How to connect to Wi-Fi network in Arch Linux?
ul_250562: Auto Connect to any Open WiFi network via CLI Command Line
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_250562: ##Wireless NIC
allow-hotplug wlan0
iface wlan0 inet manual
wpa-roam /etc/wpa_supplicant/wpa_supplicant.conf
iface open_wifi inet dhcp

ctrl_interface=DIR=/var/run/wpa_supplicant GROUP=netdev
update_config=1

##Open_Wifi
network={
    ssid=""
    key_mgmt=NONE
    id_str="open_wifi"
}

wpa_supplicant -d -i wlan0 -c /etc/wpa_supplicant/wpa_supplicant.conf -D wext

Explanations about Options.-D:
Driver to use (can be multiple drivers: nl80211,wext). (Per interface, see the
 available options below.)
Explanations about Options.-i:
Interface to listen on. Multiple instances of this option can be present, one per
 interface, separated by -N option (see below).

sudo modprobe b43

Explanations about Options.-r:
This option causes modprobe to remove rather than insert a module. If the modules it
 depends on are also unused, modprobe will try to remove them too. Unlike insertion,
 more than one module can be specified on the command line (it does not make sense to
 specify module parameters when removing modules).
Explanations about Options.-f:
Try to strip any versioning information from the module which might otherwise stop it
 from loading: this is the same as using both --force-vermagic and --force-modversion.
 Naturally, these checks are there for your protection, so using this option is
 dangerous unless you know what you are doing.

Explanations about Options.-X:
Enables X11 forwarding. This can also be specified on a per-host basis in a
 configuration file.
Explanations about Options.-f:
Requests ssh to go to background just before command execution. This is useful if
 ssh is going to ask for passwords or passphrases, but the user wants it in the
 background. This implies -n. The recommended way to start X11 programs at a remote
 site is with something like ssh -f host xterm.
Explanations about Options.-N: Do not execute a remote command. This is useful for just forwarding ports.

ul_565742: #ENABLE PACKET FORWARD
echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward

#YOU COULD JUST ENABLE FORWARD FOR EVERYTHING WITHOUT LIMITATIONS, USING INTERFACES JUST TO BE MORE SPECIFIC
iptables -A FORWARD -i enp0s3 -o enp0s8 -j ACCEPT
iptables -A FORWARD -i enp0s8 -o enp0s3 -j ACCEPT

#MASQUERADE OUTBOUND CONNECTIONS
iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o enp0s8 -j MASQUERADE

Explanations about Options.-G:
GROUP1[,GROUP2,...[,GROUPN]]]

 separated from the next by a comma, with no intervening whitespace. The groups are
 subject to the same restrictions as the group given with the -g option.
